Under Moyá's direction, Nadal improved his serve,[467][443] and incorporated serve-and-volley as a surprise tactic in some of his matches.[468] Moyá, who has known Nadal since he was 12, was more a friend than a coach, and when he realized that Nadal was going through a bad time, he left his duty as a coach and acted like a friend with whom Nadal could speak to.[462]

Francisco Roig, who was hired by Nadal in 2005, acted as the alternate coach.[462][469]

Equipment and apparel

Nike served as Nadal's clothing and shoe sponsor. Nadal's signature on-court attire entailed a variety of sleeveless shirts paired with 3/4 length capri pants.[470] For the 2009 season, Nadal adopted more-traditional on-court apparel. Nike encouraged Nadal to update his look in order to reflect his new status as the sport's top player at that time.[471] In 2009, Nadal played matches in a polo shirt specifically designed for him by Nike,[472] paired with shorts cut above the knee. Nadal wore Nike's Air CourtBallistec 2.3 tennis shoes,[473] with various customizations throughout the season, including his nickname "Rafa" on the right shoe and a stylized bull logo on the left.

Nadal used an AeroPro Drive racquet with a 4+1⁄4-inch L2 grip. As of the 2010 season[update], Nadal's racquets were painted to resemble the Babolat AeroPro Drive with Cortex GT racquet in order to market a current model that Babolat sold.[474][475] Nadal used no replacement grip, and instead wrapped two overgrips around the handle. He used Duralast 15L strings until the 2010 season, when he switched to Babolat's new, black-colored, RPM Blast string. Nadal's rackets were always strung at 55 lb (25 kg), regardless of which surface or conditions he played on.[476][477]

Off the court

In popular culture

Nadal's autobiography, Rafa, written with John Carlin, was published in August 2011.[478]

In February 2010, Rafael Nadal was featured in the music video for Shakira's "Gypsy", filmed in Barcelona. Both later denied rumours of a romantic relationship.[479] In 2016, Nadal was one of many celebrities making a cameo in the music video for RedOne's "Don't You Need Somebody".[480]

In 2018, Nadal was featured in a new ad for the 2018 tennis game Mario Tennis Aces, part of the Mario Tennis series.[481]

Nadal appeared in the 2024 documentary Federer: Twelve Final Days about Roger Federer's final tournament before his retirement, the 2022 Laver Cup.

Homages and tributes

In April 2017, the centre court of the Barcelona Open was named Pista Rafa Nadal.[482] In 2021, prior to the tournament, the French Open paid tribute to Nadal by installing a 3-metre tall steel statue at Stade Roland Garros, created by Spanish sculptor Jordi Díez Fernández.[483]

128036 Rafaelnadal is a main belt asteroid discovered in 2003 at the Observatorio Astronómico de Mallorca and named after Nadal.[484]

At both the London and Rio Olympic Games, Nadal was chosen as Spain's flag bearer. Although he had to forfeit the role in 2012 due to injury, he carried the flag during the opening ceremony of the 2016 Games, describing it as an "incredible experience".[485][486]

Philanthropy

In November 2007, Nadal launched the nonprofit Fundación Rafa Nadal with an official presentation in February 2008, at the Manacor Tennis Club in Mallorca. The foundation was created to help disadvantaged children and teenagers, offering them opportunities through sports. His wife Maria Perello works as the director of the foundation.[487]

In response to the 2010 Haiti earthquake, Nadal played in a special charity event alongside fellow top tennis players during the 2010 Australian Open called Hit for Haiti, with proceeds going to Haiti earthquake victims.[488] He participated in a follow-up charity exhibition during the 2010 Indian Wells Open, pairing with Andre Agassi in an eventual loss to Roger Federer and Pete Sampras; it raised $1 million.[489] In late 2010, Nadal played his rival Roger Federer in the two-match exhibition Match for Africa for the Roger Federer Foundation and the Rafa Nadal Foundation. The first match took place in Zürich on 21 December, and was won by Federer, while the following match was played in Madrid, and it was won by Nadal.[490]

His foundation and academy have frequently come to the aid of those in need, especially in Spain. During the Majorca flood in October 2018, Nadal, who was recovering from injury at home in Majorca, opened his tennis academy centre to the victims.[491] One day after the flood he worked personally with some friends to help the victims, being photographed lending his hand in the cleaning up process once the flood waters had receded.[492][493] Later, Nadal donated €1 million for rebuilding Sant Llorenç des Cardassar, the most affected town.[494][495] Nadal also organized other charitable activities to help repair the damage of the disaster, such as the Olazábal & Nadal charity golf tournament.[496][497][498]

To combat the ill-effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, Nadal joined with Pau Gasol and the Red Cross in June to help raise 11 million euros.[499] The proceeds in their entirety were directed towards the people suffering from the effects of the deadly virus.[499] In 2020, the Fundación Rafa Nadal pledged to support the Food Bank of Mallorca, announcing that it would aim to collect 3,000 kg of food to support 25,000 individuals in Mallorca.[500]

On the International Day of Sport on 6 April 2023, the Fundación Rafa Nadal announced that they would partner with UNESCO through its Fit for Life project, a sport-based flagship program designed to tackle physical inactivity, such as accelerating the recovery from COVID-19, mental health issues, and inequality.[501]

In 2024, The Rafa Nadal Foundation received the Laureus Sport for Good Award at the Laureus World Sports Awards 2024.[502][503]

Nadal supports or has supported other charities, such as City Harvest, Elton John AIDS Foundation, Laureus Sport for Good Foundation and Small Steps Project.[504][better source needed][505] Nadal was awarded the Arthur Ashe Humanitarian of the Year award for 2011.[506]

Sponsorships and endorsements

Nadal was sponsored by Kia Motors since 2006. He appeared in advertising campaigns for Kia as a global ambassador for the company.[507]

He became the face of Lanvin's L'Homme Sport cologne in April 2009.[508] Nadal was the international ambassador for Quely, a company from his native Mallorca that manufactures biscuits, bakery and chocolate-coated products.[509] In 2010, luxury watchmaker Richard Mille announced that he had developed an ultra-light wristwatch in collaboration with Nadal.[510]

Nadal was the face of Emporio Armani Underwear and Armani Jeans for the spring/summer 2011 collection.[511][512] This was the first time that the label had chosen a tennis player for the job.[513]

In June 2012, Nadal joined the group of sports endorsers of the PokerStars online poker cardroom.[514] Nadal won a charity poker tournament against retired Brazilian football player Ronaldo in 2014.[515]

In August 2023, Nadal signed up as the brand ambassador for the Indian IT major Infosys.[516]

Rafa Nadal Sports Centre

Nadal owns and trained at the Rafa Nadal Sports Centre (40,000 m2, 430,000 sq ft) in his hometown of Manacor, Mallorca. The centre houses the Rafa Nadal Academy, where the American International School of Mallorca is located.[517] The academy is used by both young Spanish tennis players as well as players from other countries. For instance, in 2017, the Australian tennis federation agreed to partner with Nadal's Academy to allow their players use it as their European training base.[517][518] Nadal's coach and uncle Toni Nadal is the head of the academy, his agent Carlos Costa is the head of business development, and fellow Majorcan Carlos Moyá is involved as a technical director.[517]

In 2021, a four-episode series about the Rafa Nadal Academy was aired on Amazon Prime and Movistar and was broadcast in 244 countries.[519] Nadal also owns and operates three other similar Rafa Nadal Academy/Centre facilities: the Rafa Nadal Academy Kuwait,[520] the Rafa Nadal Tennis Centre Mexico[521] and the Rafa Nadal Tennis Centre Greece.[522] The Mexico and Greece Centres opened in 2019 and the Kuwait Academy opened in 2020.[523]

As of 2024, Nadal will promote tennis in Saudi Arabia and open a Rafa Nadal Academy there.[524]

Involvement in football and other sports

Nadal is an avid football fan and his favorite clubs are RCD Mallorca and Real Madrid CF,[512] stating "when my uncle (Miguel Ángel) was playing for Barcelona, we wanted Barcelona to win. Before that, my whole family was for Real Madrid. After my uncle left the Barcelona team, then we’re all for the Real Madrid again. I have got nothing against Barcelona, but I prefer Real Madrid to win".[525] He is a fervent supporter of the Spanish national team, and he was one of six people not affiliated with the team or the national federation allowed to enter the team's locker room following Spain's victory in the 2010 FIFA World Cup Final.[526] Nadal has made several honorary kick-offs for various teams.[527][528][529][530]

In December 2007, in the "Friends of Iker v Friends of Rafa" charity sports event, the two teams contested a tennis match and a football match.[531] In December 2008, Nadal and Casillas staged a similar event, this time including an indoor football match, a tennis match, and a go-kart race.[532][533]

In July 2010, it was reported that he had become a shareholder of RCD Mallorca (owning 10%).[534] He was offered the role of vice president, which he rejected.[535] His uncle Miguel Ángel Nadal became assistant coach. Shortly after acquiring his interest in Mallorca, Nadal called out UEFA for apparent hypocrisy in ejecting the club from the 2010–11 UEFA Europa League for excessive debts.[526]

Nadal enjoys playing golf and poker.[536][537] In October 2020, Nadal competed in the professional-level Balearic Golf Championship, obtaining a World Amateur Golf Ranking in the process.[538][539]

Personal life

I love fishing for three reasons: the calm and tranquillity, the beauty of the sea –- and, of course, the satisfaction of catching your dinner. I can forget about everything. No one can call me, because I keep my mobile switched off, so I can relax and not think about tennis.[379]

— Nadal, on his love for fishing in his leisure time to the Daily Mail in 2007.

Family and beliefs

In June 2009, reports emerged that Nadal's parents, Ana María and Sebastián, had separated, following weeks of speculation about his recent struggles on the court.[540] Nadal later stated "My parents' divorce made an important change in my life. It affected me. After that, I couldn't play Wimbledon, it was tough."[379]

Nadal met his future wife, María Francisca (Mery) Perelló Pascual through his younger sister, María Isabel. They began dating in 2005, when he was 19 and she was 17, and only formalized their relationship publicly in 2007, with their engagement reported in January 2019.[541][542] In October 2019, the couple was married at the La Fortaleza castle in Port de Pollença, Majorca.[543] On 8 October 2022, they had a son named Rafael.[544] Nadal had previously commented on not starting a family early and expressed a desire to have children in the future, reflecting on the unpredictability of life during his ongoing tennis career.[545]

Mery Perelló was a sports marketer in London, but as she saw Nadal's career getting bigger, she decided to help his off-court business.[541] She now serves as the director of Fundación Rafa Nadal.[487]

Nadal was raised a Catholic, but now identifies as an agnostic atheist.[546]

Nadal's native languages are Spanish and Balearic Catalan; he speaks conversational English.[547]

Residences

When Nadal was aged 10 to 21, the extended Nadal family shared a five-storey, family-owned apartment building in Manacor.[7][10] In 2012, Nadal purchased a house in Porto Cristo for about 4 million euros, located near his family home.[548] Around the time he won the 2012 French Open, Nadal acquired a vacation home, a two-story villa in Playa Nueva Romana, in the Dominican Republic, for about 2 million euros.[549]

Other endeavors

As a young boy, he would run home from school to watch his favorite Japanese anime, Dragon Ball, and CNN dubbed him "the Dragon Ball of tennis" for his unorthodox style.[550]

Off the court, his sister described him as "a bit of a scaredy cat".[551] Since childhood, he has had a fear of the dark, preferring to sleep with a light or television on.[552] Nadal is afraid of deep water, dogs, and thunderstorms, and is nervous about riding a bicycle.[13][551]

Despite playing tennis left-handed, Nadal is right-handed in other activities.[15][553]

Health

Throughout his career, Nadal had chronic knee injuries, sidelining him from multiple tournaments. In late 2012, Nadal received over six months of physical therapy, along with platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy, a non-surgical treatment that had been previously disallowed by the World Anti-Doping Agency.[554][555]

Nadal has a rare chronic disorder of his left ankle, Mueller-Weiss syndrome, diagnosed age 19. He received anesthetic injections en route to winning the 2022 French Open.[556]

Nadal's 22 Grand Slam singles titles place him second in the men's all-time rankings, behind Djokovic's 24 titles. His 30 Grand Slam singles finals place him 3rd in the men's all-time rankings, behind Djokovic's 37 and Federer's 31 finals, respectively. He has won 14 French Open titles, an all-time record at any tournament. He is the youngest player in the Open Era to win all four majors (24 years old).
